body: @melix I've been talking to an IBM employee on the J9 development team, and he tested the issue and says that the ClassValue bug  (https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8136353) does not occur on J9.

> I've been talking to an IBM employee on the J9 development team, and he tested the issue and says that the ClassValue bug (https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8136353) does not occur on J9.

Good, I will have to double check before we accept it. As for reopening, I mean that this PR should be associated with its own ticket. If you could create one and reword your commit to include the ticket number it would help, especially because there are bots in actions too, it makes it hard to follow otherwise.
@melix I'll ask the IBM fellow to comment here so you can talk to him directly :)

@jwagenleitner Thanks for your inputs, in that case should we provide toJson(Date), toJson(Date, Format), toJson(to, format, timezone), toJson(timezone). ? And, we will have to provide the same set of stuff to Calendar as well.

Otherwise, we could do just what the bug asks - Make timeZone configurable and leave the date format fixed -  JSON_DATE_FORMAT is that ok?
Thanks! :+1:
@pickypg Thanks for this pull request. I created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7626 to track this.
I just started the vote. It will last for 72 hours. @shils Sorry for the delay.
@PascalSchumacher That's alright, thanks for letting me know. There have been more important things to vote on recently anyway.
This also contains an improvement to subList, such that elements are not stepped over twice unnecessarily
superceded by #141 and #142 and #143

One thing to discuss is whether the iterator() method should return a thread-safe operator, or leave that to clients. I believe the existing implementation was not thread-safe, so I am also happy to remove the synchronized wrapper from the PR.
merged, thanks
applied, thanks! (I ended up changing it further but your attentiveness to detail triggered the change!)

We won't have any tests covering this. I suspect it is safe to merge - just doing some checking. I think it applies all the time, not just when a custom config is specified via `-Dgrape.config`, but I think that might be OK anyway, since I don't think we ever fall back to that config, we use the one in `defaultGrapeConfig.xml`.
@paulk-asert : Any update on this?
I guess to be as backwards compatible as we can, we should just keep as strings.
Thanks for pull request. :) Can you rebase it? Thanks!

As long as the strings don't change, there is no backwards compatibility lost and compatibility is improved for newer clients. It's only for code looking for the constants that don't exist that will have issues, but they'll just have to a clear minimum version; as a future consumer of said strings, I'd much rather run into that than litter my code with magic strings.

I've been traveling a lot recently, so I'll dig this one back up and start going through to find the various necessary strings.
Thanks a lot @jwagenleitner , I have implemented your suggestions.
I did further testing and everything seems to be working well. Thanks for spotting this! I will close this once I create a Jira ticket.
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks! :+1:
Very nice addition to the Groovy Console. :+1: Thanks!  :)
Thanks!

There are two parts to this issue. The first is that ProxyGeneratorAdapter isn't mangling the generated class name correctly in the case of arrays. The second is that getKey doesn't handle arrays (which this PR fixes). I am going to split the original Jira issue to cover the two cases.
merged - thanks!
Thanks! :)
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks! :+1:
@blackdrag @melix Is this ready to merge?

I am thinking the patch does not really address the problem. The order must not matter. If it does, then there is a bug in the code that works only with a certain order. And that's the part that needs fixing with either a sorting there or not depending on sorting at all.  Furthermore, the patch addresses code of precompiled classes generated from a class object. We have also ClassNodes objects from code currently under compilation and from classes stored in jars and read by asm. Nothing in this patch asserts the order in those cases, and I think there should not be as well. As the patch is now I must fear, that if the classes inside of Groovy7363Support or moved into the assertScript part, that the test will fail again. So -1 on merging from me in the current state
Thanks! :+1:
Test failed. Did you get a automatic notification for the failures?
No, I get no mail notifications. Working on fixing...
Merged, thanks for taking a look.
two fixed, two to go...
Thanks! :)
OK, I'll move the fix to the method resolution instead of the `ClassNode` configuration.

without saying we should do this, there is at least one part that needs improvement. Your tests do not check the returned value at all. Since that is what is one deciding factor to have this method at all, I would say testing the returned value is absolutely required
yes, there currently is only one "happy path" test and the rest is the `with` test adopted.  I'll add more tests once, there is some vibe to add this function.

I pushed again, moving the fix to `ClassNode.getGetterMethod()` so it doesn't pick the first matching method that comes along, but the "best" one independently of the order, as suggested by @blackdrag.
Thanks! :+1:
Thanks, looks much better to me. @blackdrag what do you think?
I added another commit to enable the same support in the ant task.
I think we can go with that +1
Thanks!

Thanks! :+1: 

@blackdrag Thanks for the reviews. :)
Thanks!
I decided to treat the consumption of BOM as a separate issue and have opened [GROOVY-7661](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7661) to track that.
Shouldn't there be an arg to specify what encoding to use to interpret the bytes?
Please rebase rather than merge upstream commits, it keeps the commit log cleaner.
sure, I quoted you in the comments of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7502
Thanks! :+1: Nice to have this issue fixed after all those years. :)
Thanks!
I think the writeUTF16BomIfRequired() methods have the writer/outputstream as the first parameter (to be consistent with the order of parameters of the other methods). What do you think?
great work :+1:
Thanks! :+1:

Great work! Thanks a lot. :)

Just  a small nitpick: In groovy the assert statement should be `assert actual == expected` (I also get confused from time to time because the order is the opposite of JUnits `assertX(expected, actual)`).

Hi @PascalSchumacher, thanks for the reminder, I'm a little too used to the junit style.  I'd be happy to make the changes to this commit, just not sure if I should rebase the change or add on as an additional commit.
Yea, I like the idea of switching the parameter order.  Thanks for the suggestion.
Hi @jwagenleitner, please rebase (we prefer the changes done of an an issue to be a single commit). Thanks!

Looks like MalformedParameterizedTypeException has no String constructor. I suggest wrapping in for example GroovyRuntimeException instead (can't think of a better one right now... I would normally suggest ReflectiveOperationException, but that is Java7 only).
Thanks, I will update the PR
Fixed the assert argument order, thanks again for the feedback/review @PascalSchumacher
Thanks! :)

Merged: 3b85e8610fa2976dc4430f1930e6a1369a69d016 Thanks!

It would be nice if you could close the pull request (I forgot to add a comment when cherry-picking and we can not do it by hand because this is a read only-mirror.) Thanks!

A similar method named [tap](http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.0.0/Object.html#method-i-tap) exists in Ruby, and was implemented as an extension method [here](https://github.com/timyates/groovy-common-extensions#tap). As far as a vibe to add this, you'd probably get more feedback if you posted on the users mailing list.
Whoops, I guess that was a load-bearing comma. :smile:
LOL, right :)  Thanks for PR.
